posts.author: NiuHaka
posts.content:
I'm in need of an alt for those times when my RL friends aren't online. Arelith rules and limitations apply.

I'm looking for a heavily armored Human mercenary type who wields a greatsword or a bastard sword, whichever is mechanically superior. He will have some kind of special bond with his weapon so I'm thinking greatsword would be preferable so that there is more focus on weapon damage. He may be stuck soloing sometimes so survivability while killing monsters alone would be a plus.

Part of this Character's journey will be to master/conquer his weapon so some WM seems like a good class to throw in there. My best guess so far is some Fighter levels and some WM levels but i really don't know what else. Having some casting levels doesn't seem to mesh well with the concept but i could possibly be persuaded to alter the concept if the build is good. Some of the Monk feats seem great and comes with things like cleave and Imp Knockdown (a personal favorite) which frees up some options for other useful feats. Having Rogue with Sneak Attack and Knockdown could be a really good mix too and seems to fit the concept quite well.

Any help would be greatly appreciated.

posts.author: AmanoJyaku
posts.content:
I'm sure some of the more experienced guys will shoot me down in flames for this, but have you considered Blackguard? I've not played on Arelith, but having a quick look at the wiki I can see they're heavily into the RP element with some leveling restrictions. Your character could be driven to insanity, evil and even consorting with demons in his pursuit of the ultimate weapon power.

This gives you a fair few of the things you were looking for. Sneak attacks & IKD, no real casting but with the create undead & summon fiend abilities for a bit of backup when you go it alone. You can even poison your blade, if you're into that sort of thing. I'd originally envisioned this as culminating in the mighty Devastating Critical (your char loves his sword, right?), but seeing as that would be "against the law", Overwhelming will have to do.

I had a quick look for similarish builds using the search engine, and there are a few, but they're for level 40 obviously. Didn't see this class combo on the level 30 board.

Given the WM & BG requirements this is by no means a great build but I had fun seeing if I could squeeze all the feats in, and by that time it was already done, so I thought I might as well post it. On the down side, your AC and saves really suck, not much skill points to spare, bulls strength is your only buff and your summons probably won't last very long in serious combat.

posts.author: MrZork
posts.content:
Hehe. If you don't grab tumble with those rogue levels, you will be one of the few on this board who wouldn't! In terms of attacks of opportunity, it's Spring Attack that is making tumble redundant. But, what 30 ranks in tumble gives you is +6 AC. That's a big deal for any melee build (unless the tumble AC bonus is nerfed on Arelith, I guess). And, since your build is going to do his share of soloing and won't have a shield when wielding his greatsword, it's even more important to lower the damage you are taking each round.

Regarding skills, this will be very dependent on the environment and your play style. Unless sneakers are rare on Arelith (or you plan on having true sight from an item), I would trade some of that search for spot. In addition, it's a little surprising that you have taken Skill Mastery without investing in set trap. Being able to lay a mine field is a great backup plan when facing foes who are hard to hurt or who are hurting you too fast to take on directly. Of course, that is a play style thing and many players don't have the patience to set traps.

BTW, unless Arelith has lots of tough locks and traps, you could trade out some of those points in open lock and disable trap to free up some skill points for other skills, like tumble and set trap. Spellcraft isn't a bad idea since your will save is going to be poor, but those 30 skill points will only buy you a +3 save by the end of your career. And, also with that in mind, you might consider Slippery Mind for your rogue feat or Improved Evasion, depending on whether you have access to mind immunity items or scrolls. When soloing, failing a will save is often death.

From my perspective, Power Attack is of very limited value on its own. However, it is a prerequisite for Cleave, which is a very nice feat. And, that extra full-AB attack when you are swarmed is even more important when soloing.

posts.author: MrZork
posts.content:
I see what you mean that the feats are pretty tight for this toon and it will be hard to get Cleave in there. I would be tempted to trade it for Toughness, but that's a judgement call. To me, the extra 30 HP isn't worth as much as an extra full-AB attack. If you don't go for Cleave, then dropping Power Attack is a good idea. I would be tempted to take Iron Will (or Strong Soul) for a bump to will saves, but the reality is that you will really have to rely on items for that. So, maybe take KD earlier and move Expertise earlier as well so that you can take something else at at level 9. Perhaps Disarm, since you are wielding a large weapon and will have high AB and you have Mobility to mitigate the AoOs. Perhaps IKD if Arelith has plenty of enemies that are bigger than large.

The skills are hard to advise on because they depend so much on the environment. I have never played Arelith, so I really don't know the lay of the land there. And, I don't just mean the rule changes, I mean how common certain things will be as one explores the module. E.g. are there lots of DC 42 locks? Do many areas have hard-to-find hidden doors? Are the traps easy or hard to spot? Do sneaky enemy NPCs enter stealth mode? Etc. That said, what follows is how I tend to think, based on my experiences in various SP modules and places like the World of Greyhawk.

Disable Trap 12(15), Discipline 33(41), Intimidate 4(3), Open Lock 8(10), Search 18(19), Set Trap 11(15), Spot 23(22), Tumble 30(32), UMD 32(31), remaining skillpoints 27

Most places have items that improve lock picking and trap disarming skills, so it really matters how many tough locks and traps one is going to encounter. I like to get set trap up to 15, so that all of the useful non-epic traps are settable. Because a toon gets take 20 for attempts outside of combat, I tend to think that disable trap is fine at 15 or so and that open lock is good at 10 or 15 (there are Knock scrolls for tougher locks on containers and thieves' tools for hard locks marked as plot and un-Knock-able doors). Actually, since Arelith nerfs the Knock spell for doors, how much open lock to take will really depend on how common tough locks are and how available items that increase the skill are.

If there are lots of hidden doors and so on, search may be a bit higher. In reality, most modules seem designed so that few areas require high search skills to find those hidey holes. And, most of the hidden objects allow a search check every few seconds or every time a toon walks near the hidden object, so there is more than one chance to find it, if one suspects something is nearby. Similarly, many AI scripts allow stealthy NPCs to enter stealth with fairly marginal stealth skills, so spot doesn't have to be really maxed to uncloak them. If there are many serious stealthers, then maxing spot can be worthwhile. Another option is a Watchman's Helm (sometimes available in shops) and true sight items, though I see that the TS spell is very short duration on Arelith.

UMD is another variable to consider. If reliable scroll use isn't the goal, then the real issue is how many nice class- or race-restricted items are available? For low or low-mid magic modules, I find that I can use just about everything I want to with a modified UMD skill of 20 or so. But, scrolls require higher UMD skill to use reliably. (See this post for some notes about that). Using the standard Bioware implementation for UMD scroll use, your toon will need a modified UMD of 33 to cast level 9 scrolls from spells without chance of failure. 28 is needed for level 4 scrolls, like Improved Invisibility and Stoneskin. Ironically, it is usually less critical that those lows or mid-level buff spells be cast reliably, since they are typically cast before combat and a failed skill check just means a wasted scroll. Having a failed cast of Greater Sanctuary or Time Stop can be a disaster. Anyway, my point is that, depending on the items available, you can skimp on UMD, unless you are counting on scrolls for buffing.

When fleshing this out, I left 27 skill points unallocated. If one or two of the assumptions I have made above doesn't hold for Arelith, then spend them to make up the difference. E.g., if there are lots of sneakers, then keep spot maxed. If every other enemy is a taunter, then concentration becomes worthwhile for a melee toon. Etc.

There is a problem with that build, man. Disarm without Improved Disarm generates an Attack of Opportunity. I would do the following:

Go Fighter 10 Rogue 13 WM 7, get rid of Disarm and replace it with IKD, then take Crippling Strike with the Rogue 13 Bonus Feat (you will lose one fighter bonus feat and gain one Rogue bonus feat). You gain more Skill Points, +1d6 Sneak Attack damage, Crippling Strike and 2 more skill dumps, you lose disarm and delay EWS. IMO an EASY trade. I would even delay improved evasion for Crippling Strike there.

Take it EZ!

I would swap Dodge with Expertise, and Mobility with Blind Fight. Maybe take Dodge AND Expertise both at 1 and KD at 3 when your BAB will be a bit higher, cuz attempting KDs when your BAB is low, you'll miss most of the time, which brings me to the second point here. I'd delay the first Rogue level to 7th, because at level 6 Fighter-types get their second attack per round, which makes a HUGE difference. After you have that second attack and +6 to your BAB, Sneak Attack will be much more useful. Plus, you'll have all your bread and butter combat feats at that point, including WS, KD and the whole lot.

Hope this helps
